flatirons.quote: Now we're going to learn how we can use the code window to make it easier to write, test, and experiment with code. Go ahead and open replit (https://replit.com/languages/javascript)
flatirons.comment: Replit.com has a new mode called "Spooky" that is pretty much unreadable that is used by default if you do not have an account. Go to https://replit.com/languages/javascript on a clean browser (i.e. no account), and spooky will be used by default. Notice that instead of "1 console.log('Hello, world!')", it looks like "1 .log[]'Hello, World'[]" . This is easy to replicate by creating a replit account, selecting Dark or Light as your theme, typing the aforementioned, then changing the theme to "spooky" and it becomes unreadable. You should interact with replit to get them to change the default no-account display, or update your course materials, or consider an alternative like codepen.

flatirons.quote: if (name === "Alice") { ... }
flatirons.comment: Why no semicolons after {} code blocks?  I'm still not convinced that if statements with curly braces and function declarations (which are still statements, if I am correct) should not have semicolons.

flatirons.quote: switch (name) {    case "Sleepy":    case "Sneezy":    case "Happy":    case "Grumpy":    case "Bashful":    case "Dopey":    case "Doc":    characterType = "dwarf";    break;
flatirons.comment: Switch is never the cleanest or shortest solution in any of these.  All you save with a switch is removing the "variable ===" but you have to add a "break" and an extra line if you are using else ifs.  If you're not using else ifs, then you could probably concatentate, instead of a new line for each dwarf you could do a number of OR expressions in a single line of an if.

flatirons.quote: Another way of thinking about Arrays is that they are like tables that have an identifier that is a Number. If we let the identifier be a String instead of an Number, then we'd basically be describing an Object.
flatirons.comment: if identifier = number    then thing = array if identifier = string    then thing = object if number != string    then array != object  But aren't arrays a type of object?  I mean literally, the typeof object?

flatirons.quote: (which isn't surprising, given that Arrays are a special type of Object)
flatirons.comment: See last comment

flatirons.quote: We can also provide one or two arguments to .slice(): the first is the index where the slice should begin and the second is the index before which it should end:
flatirons.comment: Would this be true if an index was missing?  Or is somethng like this not an array any more? {0:10, 10:11, 100:12}  It uses numbers, just not sequential.  (Note, nothing in previous lecture said arrays needed to be sequential--but it seems they do need to be.)

flatirons.quote: Method: Spread operator (...), What it does: Add element(s) to beginning or end of array
flatirons.comment: Change to: Method: Spread operator (...), What it does: expands element(s) of array, usually to add to beginning, middle, or end of array (italicize operator)

flatirons.quote: Method: .slice(), What it does: Remove 0 or more elements, Return value: A new array containing the removed elements
flatirons.comment: Change to: Method: .slice(), What it does: Retrieve 0 or more elements, Return value: A new array containing the replaced element(s)

flatirons.quote: Let's use the spread operator to copy all of the old menu Object's properties into a new Object: ... This will create a clone of the original object and save it into a new variable.
n the above code, let age = 30 is the initialization: we're creating a variable, age, that we'll use in the next three phases of the loop.
flatirons.comment: What is a "phases" in this context?  Condition, iteration, loop body?  Those were defined as "statements" earlier.  If it's supposed to be "statements" use "statements", else define "phases."

Actually in repl, https://replit.com/languages/javascript, it shows  " letters[1]; ['b', ['c', [ 'd', [Array] ], 'f' ] ] "  the rest appear as expected, same as the instruction materials, e.g.  " letters[1][1]; //=> ["c", ["d", ["e"]], "f"] "   why does "letters[1]" appears this way? something to do with repl only going, say, 4 levels deep?

flatirons.quote: A computer fulfilling a client role has the responsibility of presenting the data that is sent from the server. Historically, these machines could be more lightly equipped (and thus cheaper). You'll generally see them drawn in diagrams or on whiteboards as laptops.
flatirons.comment: Actually, you'll typically see something with a screen.  https://www.google.com/search?q=client+network+diagram&tbm=isch  That might be a laptop, or it could be monitor with a tower, or it could just be a monitor.  That's because a client is typically what we use to "see" the data and server is typically used just to store and send the data.  Once a server is up and running, we typically don't need a monitor attached, but a client will typically always need a monitor.

flatirons.quote: And this is the essence of how the web works!
flatirons.comment: This webpage is a good place to explain web 3.0 and how it compares with web 2.0

flatirons.quote: <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style.css" >
flatirons.comment: Why no /> close tag?  Even the view-source:https://learning.flatironschool.com/courses/5703/assignments/174638?module_item_id=382302 page has examples where the link tag has no close.  There seems to be no consistency.  Shouldn't we be encouraging closing tags, even this early?  Further the next code example shows the "/>" and would likely cause confusion for new students to html.

flatirons.quote:
<link
  rel="stylesheet"
  href="https://stackpath.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/4.1.1/css/bootstrap.min.css"
/>
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="company.css" />
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="engineering-department.css" />
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="project-x-launch.css" />
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="typography.css" />
...
<title>My Site Title</title>
Notice that unlike the previous tags we've discussed, title has an opening and closing tag.
flatirons.comment:
This isn't true.  Link has close tags in the example.  And apparently should have them for XHTML:
"The <link> tag is empty, which means that the closing tag isn’t required. It contains only attributes. But in XHTML, the (<link>) tag must be closed (<link/>)."
https://www.w3docs.com/learn-html/html-link-tag.html

flatirons.quote: There are two notable things about the img tag: The first is that it does not have a closing tag. The image tag closes itself.
flatirons.comment: I would argue if it is self-closing, which it is in the example, then it has a closing tag, it just happens to be part of the opening tag, which is also a self-closing tag.  (This might be overly pedantic.)

flatirons.quote: Now, what is a relative path? You could write href="style.css" and the content of style.css would change your index.html file. But we want to teach you to require external resources (like CSS or JavaScript) by using relative paths.
flatirons.comment: That /is/ a relative path, it's just not as "crystal clear" (to use Flatiron's term) as starting with "./".

flatirons.quote: #ffffff makes white since 255 reds, 255 greens, and 255 blues equal the maximum of each of the colors.
flatirons.comment: what's not clear is why ff equals 255, I suggest something similar to dblue's answer https://forum.renoise.com/t/hexadecimal-how-does-ff-255/42658

flatirons.quote:
Some tags are self-closing like the line break element
.
flatirons.comment:
Change to: Some tags are self-closing like the line break element
.

flatirons.quote: <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="./main.css" />
flatirons.comment: Why is this the only time you put in "type="text/css" " -- if there's a best practice, it should be done each time.

flatirons.comment: Is this good practice?  Shouldn't it be topColor, firstRainbowBand or something?

There's only the conclusion which says it is a blank wall under graffiti: "With the dev tools and resources on CSS specificity rules, work your way through all seven graffiti pictures until the wall is fully clean. "
